poetic_form.description: The Euphoric Lark is a poetic narrative, originating in The Closed Hatchet. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is a single couplet. Use of simile is characteristic of the form. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures and they use the same placement of allusions. Each line has seven syllables. Every line of the poem has an initial caesura. The second line of the couplet presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The first line is intended to describe the past. The second line is intended to reflect on previous ideas concerning current events.

The Massive Duties is a reflective poetic form concerning war, originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into two couplets and another two to six couplets. Use of metaphor is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines are required to maintain phrasing. Each line has fourteen syllables. [B]The first part is intended to make an assertion. The second line of each couplet must expand the idea of the first line. [B]The second part is intended to undercut the previous assertion. The second line of each couplet must expand the idea of the first line.

The Luxurious Saffron Lilac is a light poetic form, originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. Use of consonance and vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. Each line has eight syllables. The third line of the tercet presents a different view of the subject of the second line. The first line is intended to describe the past. The second line is intended to develop the previous idea concerning current events. The third line is intended to reflect on previous ideas concerning the future.

The Dead Burial is a dramatic poetic form concerning death, originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single quintain. The Dead Burial is always written from the perspective of the author. Use of vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning. The first line has eight syllables. It has an initial caesura. The second line has ten syllables. It has an initial caesura. The third line has two syllables. It has an initial caesura. The fourth line has seven syllables. It has a terminal caesura. The fifth line has seven syllables. It has a medial caesura.

The Habitual Sister is a poetic form concerning family, originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. Each line has six syllables. The second line of the tercet reverses the grammatical structure of the first line. The second line of the tercet presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The second line of the tercet must expand the idea of the first line. The first line is dramatic and intended to make an assertion. The second line is a narrative and intended to make a counter-assertion. The third line is ribald and intended to synthesize previous ideas.

The Learned Abbey is a solemn poetic form intended to renounce the future, originating in The Poison of Scorching. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. Use of simile is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures. Every line of the poem has a terminal caesura. The first line has four syllables. The second line has nine syllables. The third line has thirteen syllables. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABB.

The Special Adventure is a poetic riddle intended to amuse the audience concerning immortality, originating in The Poison of Scorching. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is three to four sexains. Use of juxtaposition is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines sometimes have reversed word orders. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABCCAB. As a rule throughout the poem, the end rhymes don't generally match perfectly.

The Vermilion Lute is a poetic form concerning someone's character, originating in The Poison of Scorching. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into three distinct parts: a line, a couplet and a quatrain. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning and they sometimes have reversed word orders. Each line has four feet with a tone pattern of even-uneven-even. [B]The first part is intended to make an assertion. [B]The second part is intended to make a counter-assertion. Certain lines present different views of the same subject. The second line of the couplet must expand the idea of the first line. The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme. [B]The third part is intended to synthesize previous ideas. Certain lines present different views of the same subject. The third line of the quatrain must expand the idea of the first line. The rhyme scheme within this stanza is abba.

The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is three tercets. Use of assonance and consonance is characteristic of the form. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines are required to maintain phrasing and they reverse grammatical structures. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABB.

The Copper Steel is a dramatic poetic form concerning mining, originating in The Realms of Blunting. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single quatrain. Use of alliteration is characteristic of the form. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures, they use the same placement of allusions and they sometimes have reversed word orders. The first line has three feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed-stressed (qualitative cretic trimeter). The second line has five feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed-stressed (qualitative cretic pentameter). The third line has five feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed-stressed (qualitative cretic pentameter). The fourth line has two feet with an accent pattern of stressed-unstressed-stressed (qualitative cretic dimeter). The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABAA.

The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme. As a rule throughout the poem, the end rhymes don't generally match perfectly. [B]The second part is intended to make a counter-assertion. [B]The third part is intended to synthesize previous ideas. The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme.

The Earthen Irons is a poetic riddle concerning mining, originating in The Red Seducer. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. Use of simile is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures. Each line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even. Every line of the poem has an initial caesura. The first line is intended to describe the subject of the poem. The second line is intended to develop the previous idea. The third line is intended to renounce. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABB.

The Plays of Quiescence is a solemn poetic form concerning someone recently deceased, originating in The Red Seducer. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is divided into two to three couplets and two quintains. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning and they sometimes have reversed word orders. Each line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. [B]The first part is intended to express grief over the subject of the poem. The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme. [B]The second part is intended to refuse consolation. The rhyme scheme repeating in each stanza is abaca.

The Velvet of Mirth is a light poetic form concerning current events, originating in The Red Seducer. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single couplet. Use of elision and vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning. The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme. The second line of the couplet is required to maintain the phrasing of the first line. The second line of the couplet must expand the idea of the first line. The first line is intended to express grief over the subject of the poem. It has five feet with a tone pattern of even-uneven-even. The second line is intended to console the audience. It has five feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-uneven.

The Mother of Papers is a dramatic poetic form concerning someone recently deceased, originating in The Red Seducer. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. Use of elision, epenthesis, vivid imagery and juxtaposition is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines sometimes have reversed word orders. The third line of the tercet is required to maintain the phrasing of the first line. The first line is intended to make an assertion. It has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-uneven. The second line is intended to make a counter-assertion. It must make use of consonance and metaphor. It has four feet with a tone pattern of even-uneven. The third line is intended to synthesize previous ideas. It must make use of consonance. It has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABA.

The Smile of Glimmering is a dramatic poetic form concerning current events, originating in The Red Seducer. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is a single couplet. Use of vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. Each line has six syllables. Every line of the poem has a medial caesura. The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme. The second line of the couplet has the same grammatical structure as the first line. The second line of the couplet reverses the grammatical structure of the first line. The second line of the couplet presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The first line is intended to express grief over the subject of the poem. The second line is intended to refuse consolation.

The Knowledge of Plans is a solemn poetic form intended to express grief over a chosen subject, originating in The Humble Confederations. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is a single quintain. Use of assonance, metaphor and vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines reverse grammatical structures. Each line has three feet with an accent pattern of stressed-stressed (qualitative spondaic trimeter). The third line of the quintain shares the underlying meaning of the first line. The fifth line of the quintain contrasts the underlying meaning of the second line. The third line of the quintain uses the same placement of allusions as the first line. The fourth line of the quintain presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The first line must make use of alliteration and elision. The second line must make use of elision. The fourth line must make use of alliteration. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABAAA. As a rule throughout the poem, the end rhymes don't generally match perfectly.

The Silken Monk is a reflective poetic form concerning a specific wilderness region, originating in The Humble Confederations. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into a septet and two tercets. Each line has four feet with an accent pattern of stressed-stressed (qualitative spondaic tetrameter). [B]The first part is intended to make a concession. The rhyme scheme respecting the full poem is AABCBAC. [B]The second part is intended to make an assertion. The rhyme scheme respecting the full poem is CCD.

The Coastal Beaches is a poetic riddle intended to describe Thefin Beacheddoor the Walled, originating in The Humble Confederations. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single tercet. The Coastal Beaches is always written from the perspective of the author. Use of consonance is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines use the same placement of allusions. Each line has five feet with an accent pattern of unstressed-stressed-unstressed (qualitative amphibrachic pentameter). The third line of the tercet presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABB.

The Wayward Walk is a dramatic poetic form concerning a journey, originating in The Humble Confederations. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into a tercet and three couplets. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often contrast underlying meaning. Each line has five feet with an accent pattern of stressed-stressed-unstressed (qualitative antibacchic pentameter). [B]The first part is intended to make a concession. The second line of the tercet must expand the idea of the first line. The rhyme scheme within this stanza is aba. [B]The second part is intended to make an assertion. The second line of each couplet must expand the idea of the first line. The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme.

The Spittle of Tombs is a dramatic poetic form intended to express pleasure with Otsu the Snots of Spurting, originating in The Humble Confederations. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is two to four ten-line stanzas. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines sometimes have reversed word orders. Each line has nine syllables. The eighth line of each stanza presents a different view of the subject of the sixth line. The ninth line of each stanza must expand the idea of the seventh line. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABAACADBDB.

The Beloved Satin is a dramatic poetic form, originating in The Faint Cobra. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into a line and an octet. Use of ambiguity, metaphor and vivid imagery is characteristic of the form. Each line has eight syllables. [B]The first part is intended to describe the past. [B]The second part is intended to develop the previous idea concerning current events. The second line of the octet must expand the idea of the first line. The rhyme scheme within this stanza is abcdccca.

The Mauve Embraces is a poetic form concerning someone recently retired, originating in The Faint Cobra. The form guides poets during improvised performances. The poem is a single couplet. Use of assonance is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines have similar grammatical structures. The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme. The second line of the couplet must expand the idea of the first line. The first line is intended to make a concession. It has six feet with a tone pattern of even-even-uneven. The second line is intended to make an assertion. It has five feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even.

The Play of Glittering is a light poetic form, originating in The Faint Cobra. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is divided into three distinct parts: a line, another line and three tercets. Use of simile is characteristic of the form. A form of parallelism is common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often contrast underlying meaning. Each line has five feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even. [B]The first part is intended to describe the subject of the poem. [B]The second part is intended to reflect on previous ideas. [B]The third part is intended to offer a different perspective. Certain lines are required to maintain phrasing. The ending of each line of this part shares the same rhyme. As a rule throughout the poem, the end rhymes don't generally match perfectly.

The Busy Jokes is a poetic form intended to complain about alcoholic beverages, originating in The Faint Cobra. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single quintain. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines often share an underlying meaning and they sometimes have reversed word orders. The first line has five feet with a tone pattern of even-even-uneven. The second line must make use of metaphor. It has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even. The third line has five feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. The fourth line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even. The fifth line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. The rhyme scheme of the poem is ABAAA.

The Saturninity of Strategy is a reflective poetic form intended to amuse the audience concerning a historical figure, originating in The Faint Cobra. The rules of the form are applied by poets to produce individual poems which can be recited. The poem is a single quatrain. Forms of parallelism are common throughout the poem, in that certain lines are required to maintain phrasing and they sometimes have reversed word orders. The ending of each line of the poem shares the same rhyme. The second line of the quatrain presents a different view of the subject of the first line. The fourth line of the quatrain must expand the idea of the third line. The first line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. It has a terminal caesura. The second line has four feet with a tone pattern of even-even-uneven. It has a terminal caesura. The third line has four feet with a tone pattern of uneven-even-even. The fourth line has four feet with a tone pattern of even-even-even.

musical_form.description: The Wondrous Chant is a form of music used to commemorate important events originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on three adril and a gingim. The musical voices join in melody, counterpoint and harmony. The entire performance should be made sweetly and is moderately paced, and it is to be very loud. The counterpoint melody has short phrases throughout the form. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to alternate tension and repose, modulate frequently and play arpeggios. [B]The Wondrous Chant has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a brief introduction, a lengthy theme and a series of variations on the theme, a bridge-passage and a finale. [B]The introduction is voiced by the melody of the gingim. The passage has short phrases in the melody. This passage is richly layered with full chords making use of the available range. The passage is performed using the ugog scale and in the fer rhythm. [B]The theme is voiced by the melody of the adril. The passage has long phrases in the melody. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. The passage is performed using the ish scale and in free rhythm. [B]The series of variations is voiced by the melody of the gingim and the counterpoint of the adril. The passage has long phrases in the melody. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. The passage is performed using the lakish scale and in free rhythm. [B]The bridge-passage is voiced by the melody of the gingim and the counterpoint of the adril. The passage has short phrases in the melody. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. The passage is performed without preference for a scale and in the ugath rhythm. [B]The finale is voiced by the melody of the gingim and the harmony of the adril. The passage has short phrases in the melody. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. The passage is performed using the kulet scale and in the dolush rhythm. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes spaced evenly throughout the octave. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. [B]The ugog heptatonic scale is thought of as joined chords spanning a perfect fifth and a perfect fourth. These chords are named thatthil and izeg. [B]The thatthil pentachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 3rd, the 4th and the 8th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The izeg tetrachord is the 8th, the 9th, the 11th and the 13th (completing the octave) degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The ish pentatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning two perfect fourths. These chords are named gatal and emr. [B]The gatal trichord is the 1st, the 3rd and the 6th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The emr trichord is the 8th, the 9th and the 13th (completing the octave) degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The lakish pentatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning two perfect fourths. These chords are named bidok and ustos. [B]The bidok trichord is the 1st, the 2nd and the 6th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The ustos trichord is the 8th, the 12th and the 13th (completing the octave) degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The kulet hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning two perfect fourths. These chords are named alak and emr. [B]The alak tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 4th and the 6th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The fer rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The ugath rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beats are named lisig (spoken li), etg (et), erong (er) and osed (os). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The dolush rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into two bars in a 4-4 pattern. The beats are named agk (spoken ag), ucat (uc), ngrak (ng) and enir (en). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x - | x - x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Granite Amethyst is a devotional form of music directed toward the worship of Zas Tinmines the Crystalline originating in The Closed Hatchet. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on one to six zaneg and a kkdal. The musical voices are purely rhythmic. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed without preference for a scale. [B]Each zaneg always provides the rhythm. [B]The Granite Amethyst has the following structure: a theme and a brief series of variations on the theme possibly all repeated. [B]The theme is voiced by the rhythm of the zaneg. The passage should be vigorous and is at a free tempo, and it is to start loud then be immediately soft. The passage is performed in the themor rhythm. [B]The series of variations is voiced by the rhythm of the zaneg and the rhythm of the kkdal. The passage should bring a sense of motion and accelerates as it proceeds, and it is to become louder and louder. The passage is performed in free rhythm. [B]The themor rhythm is made from two patterns: the robek (considered the primary) and the okag. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The robek rhythm is a single line with three beats. The beats are named olmul (spoken ol), nokzam (no) and emuth (em). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x | [B]where x is a beat and | indicates a bar. [B]The okag rhythm is a single line with eight beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x - x x x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Lark of Verses is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. One to five chanters recite The Euphoric Lark while the music is played on a kenis, a ssun and one to three segun. The musical voices cover melody, harmony and rhythm. The entire performance should be vigorous and is moderately fast. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. It is performed using the bemng scale and in the ingish rhythm. [B]Each chanter always provides the rhythm. [B]The kenis always does harmony. [B]The ssun always provides the rhythm. [B]Each segun always does the main melody and matches notes and syllables. [B]The Lark of Verses has a well-defined multi-passage structure: an introduction, a lengthy passage, a lengthy bridge-passage and a brief finale. [B]The introduction is to be very soft. Each of the segun stays in the flat middle register, the kenis ranges from the heavy low register to the strident high register, each of the chanters' voices ranges from the low register to the middle register and the ssun ranges from the ringing low register to the dull middle register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. [B]The simple passage is to be very soft. Each of the segun stays in the flat middle register, the kenis covers its entire range from the heavy low register to the raspy top register, each of the chanters' voices covers its entire range and the ssun ranges from the dull middle register to the crisp top register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The bridge-passage is to be very loud. Each of the segun stays in the flat middle register, the kenis covers its entire range from the heavy low register to the raspy top register, each of the chanters' voices ranges from the low register to the middle register and the ssun is confined to the dull middle register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The finale is to be moderately loud. Each of the segun covers its entire range from the wobbling low register to the rugged high register, the kenis is confined to the raucous middle register, each of the chanters' voices ranges from the low register to the middle register and the ssun ranges from the dull middle register to the slicing high register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes spaced evenly throughout the octave. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. [B]The bemng hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning two perfect fourths. These chords are named bidok and mabdug. [B]The bidok trichord is the 1st, the 2nd and the 6th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The mabdug tetrachord is the 8th, the 9th, the 10th and the 13th (completing the octave) degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The ingish rhythm is made from two patterns: the okag (considered the primary) and the nazush. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The okag rhythm is a single line with eight beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x - x x x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The nazush rhythm is a single line with three beats. The beats are named nashon (spoken na), trid (t) and enr (en). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Laces of Fanciness is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Closed Hatchet. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites any composition of The Massive Duties. The entire performance should evoke tears. The melody has phrases of varied length throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed without preference for a scale and in the okag rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to use grace notes and play legato. [B]The chanter always does the main melody. [B]The Laces of Fanciness has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a theme and a series of variations on the theme and a finale. [B]The theme is consistently slowing, and it is to fade into silence. The chanter's voice stays in the middle register. [B]The series of variations accelerates as it proceeds, and it is to be in whispered undertones. The chanter's voice stays in the middle register. [B]The finale moves more quickly than the last passage, and it is to be very loud. The chanter's voice covers its entire range. [B]The okag rhythm is a single line with eight beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x - x x x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Pregnancy of Pantomimes is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Poison of Scorching. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on a baspu. The entire performance is very slow. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed without preference for a scale. [B]The baspu always provides the rhythm, should bring a sense of motion and adds fills. [B]The Pregnancy of Pantomimes has the following structure: one to two passages and an additional passage possibly all repeated. [B]Each of the first simple passages is to be moderately loud. Each passage is performed in the tuxxu rhythm. [B]The second simple passage is to be very soft. The passage is performed in the osmze rhythm. [B]The tuxxu rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into eight bars in a 4-4-4-4-4-4-4-4 pattern. The beats are named ugas (spoken ug), ustrok (us), gosma (go) and kbu (k). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x - | x x x x | - x - - | x x - x | - x x - | x x - - | - - - x | x - x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The osmze rhythm is made from two patterns: the zaxo (considered the primary) and the tuxxu. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The zaxo rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Glittery Tone is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Poison of Scorching. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. Two chanters recite nonsensical words and sounds while the music is played on a dab. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance is at a hurried pace, and it is to fade into silence. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. Throughout, when possible, performers are to play arpeggios. [B]Each chanter always does the main melody and should perform with skill. [B]The dab always should be fiery. [B]The Glittery Tone has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a theme and one to two series of variations on the theme and a coda. [B]The theme is voiced by the melody of the chanters reciting any composition of The Special Adventure. Each of the chanters' voices stays in the high register. The passage is performed using the nuklat scale and in free rhythm. [B]Each of the series of variations is voiced by the melody of the chanters reciting nonsensical words and sounds and the rhythm of the dab. Each of the chanters' voices ranges from the middle register to the high register. Each passage is performed using the slusna scale and in the smug rhythm. Each passage should be performed using grace notes and locally improvisation. Each passage should often include a rising melody pattern with sharpened third degree as well as glides and trills, often include a rising-falling melody pattern, often include a falling-rising melody pattern with flattened third degree on the rise as well as glides, trills, staccato and legato and sometimes include a falling melody pattern. [B]The coda is voiced by the melody of the chanters reciting nonsensical words and sounds and the rhythm of the dab. Each of the chanters' voices ranges from the middle register to the high register. The passage is performed without preference for a scale and in free rhythm. [B]Scales are constructed from twelve notes spaced evenly throughout the octave. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. After a scale is constructed, notes are named according to degree. The names are usmdas (spoken us), uto (ut), nol (no), dab (da), agun (ag), ung (ung) and stotho (sto). [B]The nuklat heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning a tritone and a perfect fourth. These chords are named abo and ok. [B]The abo tetrachord is the 1st, the 4th, the 6th and the 7th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The ok tetrachord is the 8th, the 10th, the 12th and the 13th (completing the octave) degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The slusna hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords spanning a tritone and a perfect fourth. These chords are named lbu and ok. [B]The lbu trichord is the 1st, the 2nd and the 7th degrees of the semitone octave scale. [B]The smug rhythm is made from two patterns: the bor and the zaxo. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The bor rhythm is a single line with sixteen beats divided into four bars in a 4-4-4-4 pattern. The beats are named osm (spoken osm), enu (en), stl (st) and zak (za). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x x | x x x x | x - - x | x x x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The zaxo rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Amethyst Luxury is a devotional form of music originating in The Poison of Scorching. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites nonsensical words and sounds. The entire performance should be made with skill. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. The music repeats for as long as necessary. It is performed without preference for a scale and in free rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to play arpeggios. [B]The chanter always does the main melody. The voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. [B]The Amethyst Luxury has a simple structure: a passage. [B]The simple passage is at a free tempo, and it is to become softer and softer.

The Wonders of Bewildering is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Realms of Blunting. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. A speaker recites nonsensical words and sounds while the music is played on a agtha. The musical voices are joined in melody. The melody has long phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. The music repeats for as long as necessary. It is performed using the nithros scale and in the umo rhythm. [B]The speaker always should feel mysterious. [B]The agtha always does the main melody, should be melancholic and uses mordents. [B]The Wonders of Bewildering has the following structure: a lengthy passage and a finale. [B]The simple passage is very fast, and it is to be in whispered undertones. The agtha is confined to the strident high register. [B]The finale is moderately fast, and it is to be moderately loud. The agtha ranges from the wispy middle register to the strident high register. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. A single note in the fundamental scale is named. It is called stalcon (spoken sta, 7th). [B]As always, the nithros hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named use and woge. [B]The use tetrachord is the 1st, the 4th, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The woge trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The umo rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beats are named rostfen (spoken ro) and hier (hi). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x | [B]where x is a beat and | indicates a bar.

The Sable Sparkles is a devotional form of music originating in The Realms of Blunting. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. A chanter recites nonsensical words and sounds. The entire performance should be bright and is at a free tempo. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed in the ani rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to play legato. [B]The chanter always does the main melody. The voice stays in the low register. [B]The Sable Sparkles has a simple structure: three to four unrelated passages. [B]Each of the simple passages is to start loud then be immediately soft. Each passage is performed using the ramet scale. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. A single note in the fundamental scale is named. It is called stalcon (spoken sta, 7th). [B]As always, the ramet pentatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named agtha and idla. [B]The agtha trichord is the 1st, the 2nd and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The idla trichord is the 1st, the 7th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The ani rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beats are named shato (spoken sha) and almef (al). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x'- | [B]where ' marks a beat as late, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Adorable Song is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Realms of Blunting. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on a agtha. The entire performance is to be very loud. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed in free rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to make trills and play arpeggios. [B]The agtha always does the main melody and should build as the performance proceeds. [B]The Adorable Song has a well-defined multi-passage structure: an introduction, a theme and one to two series of variations on the theme, a bridge-passage and a lengthy finale. [B]The introduction is at a walking pace. The agtha ranges from the wispy middle register to the strident high register. The passage is performed using the tunem scale. [B]The theme is at a hurried pace. The agtha is confined to the wispy middle register. The passage is performed using the dik scale. [B]Each of the series of variations is moderately paced. The agtha covers its entire range from the raucous low register to the rippling top register. Each passage is performed using the icmon scale. [B]The bridge-passage is consistently slowing. The agtha is confined to the rippling top register. The passage is performed using the ozi scale. [B]The finale is very slow. The agtha covers its entire range from the raucous low register to the rippling top register. The passage is performed using the tunem scale. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. A single note in the fundamental scale is named. It is called stalcon (spoken sta, 7th). [B]As always, the tunem heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named ilpi and rom. [B]The ilpi tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The rom tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the dik heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named thad and rom. [B]The thad tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the icmon hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named thad and idla. [B]The idla trichord is the 1st, the 7th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the ozi heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named ilpi and kasmko. [B]The kasmko tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 4th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division.

The Chartreuse Lute is a form of music used to commemorate important events originating in The Fish of Strife. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. Three chanters recite any composition of The Ocean of Oars while the music is played on a metha. The musical voices bring melody with harmony. The entire performance should be delicate and accelerates as it proceeds, and it is to be moderately soft. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. It is performed without preference for a scale and in the cida rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to alternate tension and repose. The voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. [B]The metha always does the main melody. [B]The Chartreuse Lute has a well-defined multi-passage structure: an introduction and a verse and a chorus possibly all repeated. [B]The introduction is voiced by the melody of the metha and the harmony of the chanters. The metha ranges from the crisp low register to the flat middle register and each of the chanters' voices ranges from the middle register to the high register. This passage is richly layered with full chords making use of the available range. [B]The verse is voiced by the melody of the metha. The metha ranges from the crisp low register to the flat middle register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. [B]The chorus is voiced by the melody of the metha. The metha ranges from the flat middle register to the crisp high register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. [B]The cida rhythm is made from two patterns: the le and the timafi. [B]The le rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into four bars in a 2-2-2-2 pattern. The beats are named atha (spoken ath) and alo (al). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x | - x'| x - | x`- | [B]where ` marks a beat as early, ' marks a beat as late, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The timafi rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into four bars in a 2-2-2-2 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - | x x | x - | - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Mauve Trumpets is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Fish of Strife. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on a dveli. The entire performance should be made with skill and is fast. The melody has short phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. The music repeats for as long as necessary. It is performed using the aweme scale and in the le rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to alternate tension and repose and play arpeggios. [B]The dveli always does the main melody. [B]The Mauve Trumpets has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a lengthy introduction, a chorus and a brief verse all repeated two times, a bridge-passage and a verse and a chorus. [B]The introduction is to be moderately soft. [B]The first chorus is to be very loud. [B]The first verse is to become softer and softer. [B]The bridge-passage is to be moderately loud. [B]The second verse is to fade into silence. [B]The second chorus is to be moderately soft. The passage should be performed using staccato. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]As always, the aweme hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named eyo and datha. [B]The eyo trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The datha tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The le rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into four bars in a 8-8-8-8 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x x x x`- - - | - x - - x x x - | - - - - - x`- - | - x - - - - - - | [B]where ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Play of Songs is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Fish of Strife. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites any composition of The Scholar of Wisdom while the music is played on a ba. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance should be fiery. The melody has long phrases throughout the form. It is performed in the timafi rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to use mordents, add fills and spread syllables over many notes. [B]The chanter always provides the rhythm and is to be loud. [B]The ba always does the main melody, is to be moderately soft and glides from note to note. [B]The Play of Songs has the following structure: a theme and one to two series of variations on the theme possibly all repeated. [B]The theme is at a walking pace. The ba covers its entire range from the rich low register to the wavering high register and the chanter's voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. The passage is performed using the atho scale. The passage should be composed and performed using trills. [B]Each of the series of variations is slower than the last passage. The ba stays in the rich low register and the chanter's voice ranges from the low register to the middle register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. Each passage is performed using the datome scale. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]As always, the atho heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named adi and datha. [B]The adi tetrachord is the 1st, the 4th, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The datha tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the datome heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named adi and thili. [B]The thili tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 7th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The timafi rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into four bars in a 2-2-2-2 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - | x x | x - | - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Glimmer of Rhyme is a devotional form of music originating in The Fish of Strife. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The music is played on a metha, a ecafe and two dveli. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance should evoke tears. It is performed using the fena scale. Throughout, when possible, performers are to modulate frequently. [B]The metha always does the main melody and locally improvises. [B]The ecafe always provides the rhythm. [B]Each dveli always does the main melody and locally improvises. [B]The Glimmer of Rhyme has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a theme, a bridge-passage and a series of variations on the theme. [B]The theme accelerates as it proceeds, and it is to start loud then be immediately soft. The metha ranges from the flat middle register to the crisp high register and the ecafe stays in the raucous high register. The passage has mid-length phrases in the melody. This passage is richly layered with full chords making use of the available range. The passage is performed in the avea rhythm. The passage should be performed using glides. [B]The bridge-passage is at a walking pace, and it is to be very loud. The metha ranges from the flat middle register to the crisp high register and the ecafe covers its entire range from the strident low register to the raucous high register. The passage has phrases of varied length in the melody. This passage typically has some sparse chords. The passage is performed in the nanotha rhythm. [B]The series of variations slows and broadens, and it is to be moderately soft. The metha covers its entire range and the ecafe covers its entire range from the strident low register to the raucous high register. The passage has mid-length phrases in the melody. This passage typically has some sparse chords. The passage is performed in the dinade rhythm. The passage should be performed using glides. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]As always, the fena heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named ar and fathinu. [B]The ar tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 4th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The fathinu tetrachord is the 1st, the 4th, the 7th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The avea rhythm is a single line with sixteen beats divided into two bars in a 8-8 pattern. The beats are named mafina (spoken ma), pama (pa), bulifo (bu), ada (ad), icithi (ic), arle (ar), opa (op) and eli (el). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x - x - - x x | x - x x x x x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The nanotha rhythm is made from two patterns: the aratha (considered the primary) and the le. [B]The aratha rhythm is a single line with eight beats. The beats are named imeri (spoken im), thna (th), arazi (ar), fidale (fi), tarathe (ta), cuthefi (cu), cede (ce) and otoga (ot). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - - x - - - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The le rhythm is a single line with eight beats divided into four bars in a 2-2-2-2 pattern. The beats are named atha (spoken ath) and alo (al). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x | - x'| x - | x`- | [B]where ` marks a beat as early, ' marks a beat as late, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The dinade rhythm is a single line with sixteen beats divided into four bars in a 4-4-4-4 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - - x`| x - - - | x x`- x | - - - x`| [B]where ` marks a beat as early, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Sensual Sweetness-Tone is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Barbarity of Rain. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. Three speakers recite any composition of The Strategic Laces while the music is played on a mra, two erxut and a oxam. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The entire performance should feel mysterious. The melody has mid-length phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed using the xenmu scale and in the ron rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to syncopate, modulate frequently and play legato. [B]The mra always does the main melody and spreads syllables over many notes. [B]Each erxut always provides the rhythm. [B]The oxam always provides the rhythm. [B]The Sensual Sweetness-Tone has the following structure: an introduction and three to five lengthy unrelated passages. [B]The introduction is consistently slowing, and it is to fade into silence. The mra stays in the strident high register. [B]Each of the simple passages is extremely fast, and it is to be soft. The mra stays in the fragile low register. Each passage should be performed using rapid runs. [B]Scales are constructed from nineteen notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1xxx-x-xxxx-xxxxxx-xx-xxO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The xenmu hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 3rd, the 4th, the 10th, the 15th and the 17th. [B]The ron rhythm is made from two patterns: the tuxxu (considered the primary) and the odu. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The tuxxu rhythm is a single line with nineteen beats divided into three bars in a 6-6-7 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| X x - x - - | - - - x - - | - x x - - - - | [B]where X marks an accented beat, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The odu rhythm is a single line with two beats. The beats are named nuklat (spoken nu) and ost (ost). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Music of Pantomimes is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Barbarity of Rain. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites any composition of The Wisp of Intricacy. The entire performance should bring a sense of motion. The melody has long phrases throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed in the zaxo rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to play arpeggios and spread syllables over many notes. [B]The chanter always does the main melody. [B]The Music of Pantomimes has the following structure: a theme and one to two series of variations on the theme. [B]The theme is extremely fast, and it is to become louder and louder. The chanter's voice stays in the middle register. The passage is performed using the abo scale. [B]Each of the series of variations is moderately paced, and it is to be moderately soft. The chanter's voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. Each passage is performed using the ngub scale. [B]Scales are constructed from nineteen notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1xxx-x-xxxx-xxxxxx-xx-xxO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The abo heptatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 4th, the 6th, the 11th, the 12th, the 16th and the 19th. [B]The ngub hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 3rd, the 5th, the 13th, the 15th and the 16th. [B]The zaxo rhythm is made from three patterns: the osm (considered the primary), the urdu and the asmuk. The patterns are to be played in the same beat, allowing one to repeat before the other is concluded. [B]The osm rhythm is a single line with twenty-four beats divided into eight bars in a 3-3-3-3-3-3-3-3 pattern. The beats are named enu (spoken en), stl (st) and zak (za). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x | - x x | - x - | x X x | - x - | x - x | x x - | - x - | [B]where X marks an accented beat, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The urdu rhythm is a single line with thirty-two beats divided into four bars in a 8-8-8-8 pattern. The beats are named usmdas (spoken us), uto (ut), nol (no), dab (da), agun (ag), ung (ung), stotho (sto) and bor (bo). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - X x x x x - - | x x X x x x x x | - X x x - x - - | x - x - x - - ! | [B]where ! marks the primary accent, X marks an accented beat, x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The asmuk rhythm is a single line with seven beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - - - - x x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Lyrical Styles is a devotional form of music originating in The Barbarity of Rain. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. A singer recites any composition of The Strategic Laces while the music is played on a muk and a otsta. The musical voices join in melody and counterpoint, harmony and rhythm. The melody has phrases of varied length, while the counterpoint has mid-length phrases throughout the form. It is performed in free rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to play rapid runs. [B]The singer always should be passionate and plays arpeggios. [B]The muk always should be passionate. [B]The otsta always should feel mysterious and plays arpeggios. [B]The Lyrical Styles has a well-defined multi-passage structure: an introduction and a passage and another one to two passages. [B]The introduction is voiced by the melody of the singer, the harmony of the otsta and the rhythm of the muk. The passage is moderately fast, and it is to fade into silence. The singer's voice ranges from the low register to the middle register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. The passage is performed using the ogo scale. [B]The first simple passage is voiced by the melody of the muk. The passage is at a free tempo, and it is to be moderately loud. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. The passage is performed using the lsm scale. The passage should be performed using syllabic phrasing. [B]Each of the second simple passages is voiced by the melody of the otsta, the counterpoint of the singer and the harmony of the muk. Each passage is half the tempo of the last passage, and it is to be moderately loud. The singer's voice stays in the low register. This passage features only melodic tones and intervals. Each passage is performed using the usnusp scale. [B]Scales are constructed from nineteen notes dividing the octave. In quartertones, their spacing is roughly 1xxx-x-xxxx-xxxxxx-xx-xxO, where 1 is the tonic, O marks the octave and x marks other notes. The tonic note is fixed only at the time of performance. [B]The ogo hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 4th, the 5th, the 11th, the 13th and the 18th. [B]The lsm hexatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 3rd, the 8th, the 10th, the 14th and the 18th. [B]The usnusp heptatonic scale is constructed by selection of degrees from the fundamental scale. The degrees selected are the 1st, the 3rd, the 8th, the 10th, the 13th, the 17th and the 19th.

The Poem of Pantomiming is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Moral Wisps. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. The music is played on two rise and two vare. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The melody has long phrases throughout the form. The music is broadly layered with chords spanning the range. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to use grace notes. [B]Each rise always provides the rhythm, should be fiery and is to be moderately loud. [B]Each vare always does the main melody, should perform with feeling and is to be very soft. [B]The Poem of Pantomiming has the following structure: an introduction and three lengthy unrelated passages. [B]The introduction is at a free tempo. Each of the vare stays in the sweet low register and each of the rise covers its entire range from the eerie low register to the muddy high register. The passage is performed using the cebela scale and in the bulifo rhythm. [B]Each of the simple passages accelerates as it proceeds. Each of the vare stays in the flat middle register and each of the rise stays in the muddy high register. Each passage is performed without preference for a scale and in free rhythm. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. Every note is named. The names are datome (spoken da), lari (la), aratha (ar), imeri (im), thna (th), fidale (fi), tarathe (ta) and cuthefi (cu). [B]As always, the cebela heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named eyo and warer. [B]The eyo tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 4th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The warer tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The bulifo rhythm is made from two patterns: the dinade (considered the primary) and the emu. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The dinade rhythm is a single line with three beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The emu rhythm is a single line with sixteen beats divided into eight bars in a 2-2-2-2-2-2-2-2 pattern. The beats are named pe (spoken p) and amama (am). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - x | x - | - x | x - | - x | x - | - x | - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Mauve Tones is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Moral Wisps. The Goldenrod Leaves is a devotional form of music directed toward the worship of Thit Moistenwash originating in The Moral Wisps. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. The rise stays in the muddy high register and each of the vare ranges from the flat middle register to the dull high register. [B]Each of the second simple passages moves more quickly than the last passage, and it is to be in whispered undertones. The rise stays in the eerie low register and each of the vare ranges from the sweet low register to the flat middle register. The beats are named ustos (spoken us) and emr (em). The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| x x | [B]where x is a beat and | indicates a bar.
